free_text.Learning outcomes: The course will be given in 14 weekly sessions, each either a 2h lecture or 1.5h lecture followed by 30 min presentation by one of the attendees and a guided group discussion. Presenters will discuss original papers related to this day's lecture topic.[br/]
free_text.Content: 1. Overview of different types of cell motility. Mechanisms of bacterial motility and chemotaxis. [br/]2. Eucaryotic cell motility: flagellated and ciliated cells, crawling cell motility.[br/]3. Motile machinery: types of the cytoskeletal structures, principles of assembly of cytoskeletal filaments (treadmilling, dynamic instability).[br/]4. Motile machinery: accessory proteins, regulation of assembly and supramolecular organization of the cytoskeleton.[br/]5. Methods to study cytoskeletal dynamics: live digital fluorescence microscopy, photoactivation, photobleaching, fluorescence speckle microscopy, and others.[br/]6. Mechanisms of actin assembly in protrusion at the leading edge of the cell. [br/]7. Biophysics of protrusion, forces and modeling.[br/]8. Cell-substrate attachment: molecular composition and dynamics of adhesion sites. [br/]9. Introduction to motor proteins, active cycle, steps and forces.[br/]10. Microtubule-dependent motors, role in intracellular transport and mitosis.[br/]11. Myosin superfamily of motor proteins, non-conventional myosins in intracellular transport and hearing.[br/]12. Myosin II, coordination of protrusion, attachment and contraction in the cell translocation.[br/]13. Signaling to motility and the origins of cell polarity (directional sensing in chemotaxis, PH-domain proteins, small GTPases, calcium).[br/]14. Interaction between actin and microtubules in cell polarization and motility (budding yeast model, animal cell mitosis and cytokinesis, cell migration).[br/][br/]
free_text.Keywords: cell migration, cytoskeleton, actin, myosin, microtubules[br/]
free_text.Note: This course requires a minimum of 4 participants and is limited to 10 participants.
